Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Seeds, Soil, and Politics Workshop (September 9-14, 2016, University of California, Santa Cruz)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports international participant travel to a workshop to be held at the University of California, Santa Cruz, September 9-14, 2016. The workshop will bring together researchers who are studying the effects of contemporary developments in food production. Throughout the world, a multitude of factors such as intellectual property laws, genetic engineering, soil health, water scarcity, climatic disruptions, governance and technological change are altering the food provisioning landscape. While each of these factors have been studied in isolation or in relation to one or two others, little is known about how they all come together and whether there are common patterns despite the diversity of societies, governance structures, and environments. This workshop aims to begin to fill that gap, with a particular focus on how the changes filter down to the local level. The workshop is important because it provides a holistic perspective across scales on issues that affect food security everywhere, including in the United States.

The workshop is organized around three themes: (1) regulatory systems; (2) local farming practices; and (3) farmer and owner participatory mechanisms. Workshop participants will prepare and circulate papers in advance. The four days of the workshop will be devoted to cumulative discussion, identifying common patterns and processes, and identifying information gaps and future research needs. Findings from the research will be of interest to policy makers, as well as to researchers trying to understand how global trends affect food provisioning at local levels. The award also supports international research collaboration and therefore an improved learning experience for participating graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The participants of this workshop analyzed new forms of public and private governance over seeds and soils, how these influence farmers engagement, and how citizens mobilize to regain control over the seeds and soils on which their daily sustenance, their health and well-being depend. By considering the relationship of farmers with the living things of soil and seeds together with their relationship to different forms of national and international policy-making, these anthropologists engaged a comprehensive approach to examine how environmental change is co-created through policies and practices.

On the first day we visited the renown UC Santa Cruz farm which has trained multiple generations of organic farmers from around the world for nearly five decades. Then in anintroductory roundtable we presented our research interest to each another addressing the following questions: What are your terms of engagement with seeds, soils and politics? Why do you care? How do you see these three entities (seeds, soils and politics) interacting?The second day focused on public and private governance of agriculture. The contributors pushed the boundaries of an institutional approach to examine paradoxes of private and public governance: the role of farmers in actively embracing the governance structures that came to control them, their role in dismantling or transforming cooperative structures into private corporations, the public relations strategies of multinational corporations and their attempts to divide and rule rural communities and cooperatives, the impact of private contracts that farmersvoluntarily entered into. The ethnographic details showed the limits of the laws, regulations and certifications, their paradoxes, non-enforcements, the spaces of subborn refusal. We considered the question: is there a space outside state and markets, a space of commons, of cooperation or solidarity? Participants then looked at the tensions and contradictions within these spaces, at their overlapping boundaries. The third day focused on soils and their relationships with humans from different perspectives: from natural science, big data, diverses communities of soil organisms, nationalist nativist farmers practicing natural farming. We examined the diverse forms of knowledge and knowing linked to soils, clean science versus messy science, big data accumulated about soils, through GPS systems and computers mounted on farm equipment. The questions we discussed concerned how new agricultural data would be used, who are its curators, how is it traded? The notion of the techno-soil, the abstracted soil, clashes with other forms of problematic attachment, where the care for the soil is linked to nationalist and nativist sentiment. We examined what relationships of affect were created through physical, sensorial attachment to soils? Can soil build communities? What communities are needed to take care of the soil once again? On the fourth day participants explored how the intimacies of everyday seed saving and exchange translated into broader political action and regulation, and how, in reverse, regulatory changes affected intimacy. We looked at the complex interrelationship of dependence that control over seed establishes, when landlords gift high yielding varieties to their tenants, when husbands claim control over seeds that women selected and of course when intellectual property rights that lay dormant are suddenly enforced or seed standards become "second nature". Participants reviewed how Green Revolution varieties spread surreptitiously in many countries, how laws were introduced in many Latin American countries signatories of CAFTA that prohibit farmers the saving of seeds from their previous harvest without encountering substantial resistance.  On the fifth day, discussions focused on citizenship and mobilisation. We examined forms of self-governance, mobilization and care where laws and regulations are not immediately effective, where people are confronted with toxic food, with hunger and scarcity. We concluded that medical anthropology and environmental anthropology have to work together and look at the interplay between attempts at governing and people's responses.  We explored the tension between private and public certification schemes and attempts at self-certification, where small organic farmers not only in marginal places, but also in populous countries which create spaces of intention and protection that try to collaborate with the outside while protecting themselves from its demands and constraints as well as the tensions and contradictions that arise.The sixth day reminded participants of how fieldwork recognizes the complexities of real life experiences which enables us to constantly rework and rethink the concepts we often use, such as resilience, (food) sovereignty, in addition to forest and field, seed and soil. In the afternoon we were based at the Louden Nelson community center in Santa Cruz to discuss our ideas and questions with a well attending public of food activists, farmers, media and consumers.

As an immediate outcome of this workshop we agreed to each write an ethnographic brief to link with one of the key ideas we discussed and publish this collection as a small volume and possibly digital edition. One of the participants volunteered to organize a follow-up workshop within 2-3 years.
